lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct places and ways to travel.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “It’s between the post office and the bakery.” Students point to or circle the place on a printed town map.
stretchStrategies: My Town, My Travel – Students design a mini “my town” map in groups. They write and share 2–3 sentences: “I go to the bank by bike.” “The pet shop is next to the hospital.” Adds creativity + personalised use of grammar.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write about places in their town and how they travel to them using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Provide sentence starters on the board: “I go to the ___ by ___.” Students complete 2–3 sentences in notebooks or mini whiteboards.
stretchStrategies: My Town, My Travel – Students design a mini “my town” map in groups. They write and share 2–3 sentences: “I go to the bank by bike.” “The pet shop is next to the hospital.” Adds creativity + personalised use of grammar.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can present about their town and how they travel to different places using complete sentences.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Collaboration) In groups, students draw a simple town map and present how they get to each place using target sentences.
stretchStrategies: My Town, My Travel – Students design a mini “my town” map in groups. They write and share 2–3 sentences: “I go to the bank by bike.” “The pet shop is next to the hospital.” Adds creativity + personalised use of grammar.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

Certain common places will not overlap in style or popular concept with their Western equivalents (fire station, post office, bakery, library), whereas others are more comparable (hair salon, shopping centre)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
